Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Development of a Human Centered Methodology for the Assessment of Wireless Computing Devices Used to Support Communication Flow in High Consequence Emergency Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the PI will work with partners in the Caribbean to explore the application of information technology in disaster response, in an effort to better understand the human dimension of IT used in multiple phases of emergency preparation, management and mitigation. The focus will be on the use of wireless computing resources to support communication flow in high consequence emergency management environments, because wireless technology is proving to be the most resilient form of communication during emergency situations. The PI and her team will study emerging practices throughout the phases of the disaster management continuum, with the goal of developing human centered principles to guide the selection, application and assessment of wireless hand-held communication devices to support emergency management. The PI notes that her review of the literature has revealed no evidence or history of research on human centric evaluation of hand-held communication tools, yet the human is the most critical element in the system. In this research the PI hopes to establish basic principles relating to issues such as efficiency, safety, accuracy and ease of communication in the international emergency management community.

Broader Impacts: The project will advance our understanding of communication in emergency management and will provide a foundation for modeling communication for island nations in emergency management. Technology is essential, but if an appropriate and valid communication protocol is not applied the technology can be rendered useless. Thus, the study of communications models in emergency management is critical. The PI has established a partnership with the College of the Bahamas to develop a research program that provides the environment, resources and expertise to accomplish the research goals. Additionally, the team has developed a plan to transition the research into the classroom as well as into research experiences for undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to develop a robust, human centered methodology for the assessment of wireless computing devices used to support communication flow in high consequence emergency management with applicability in the U.S, Caribbean and other island nations.  

 The objective of this study was to develop human centered principles to guide the assessment, application and selection of wireless hand-held communication devices to support emergency management and to create a mathematical model for measuring the human factors and ergonomics characteristics of mobile devices. The result was the establishment of a research agenda in the field of study known as human factors and ergonomics in high consequence emergency management.

A detailed review of the literature was performed and two data collection activities were conducted in the Bahamas: one involving emergency management officials (EMOs) and one included civilians, to determine the background information of the participants, communication habits, wireless devices currently in use, wireless services to which they have access, and feedback on device performance and usability factors. Since a large percentage of the devices used in the Bahamas are imported without documented records and not through the Bahamas Telecommunications Company (BTC), such surveys were required to determine which devices are most frequently used in the Bahamas.  Similar data was collected at the Florida Governor's Hurricane Conference.  

Once the most commonly used devices were identified, they were analyzed in terms of their capabilities, requirements, advantages, and disadvantages.   A focus group interview was held at the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) office in Nassau, Bahamas with subject matter experts representing the various emergency support functions and affiliated organizations.  Based on these interviews and the existing body of knowledge, a device selection model was developed which incorporates the following factors: durability, battery characteristics, accommodation to operational conditions, text entry, grip, screen size, portability, audio clarity, usability, and unit cost. A similar focus group was held at the Florida Governor's Hurricane Conference.

This data was used as the basis in the establishment of a mathematical model for quantifying the human factors rating for mobile devices in disaster management. This model can be used by researchers, practitioners and organizations to assess the most appropriate mobile technology to support their communication needs in emergency management. 

 

Specific Project Outcomes include the following:

1. Validated human centric methodology for assessing mobile technology use in emergency management

2. A fuzzy quantitative mathematical model to assess and measure the human factors and ergonomics aspects of mobile device use in emergency management.

 

International Collaboration Establishment

1.   Established international collaborations with Massey University in New Zealand in the area of Human Factors in Disaster Management, 2011-2012

2.   Lead NSF funded international workshop on Human Factors in Disaster Management

Collaboration with the New Universities of Lisbon, 2012

3.   International collaborations with two Romanian Universities
